reviewText: It's great to finally have the opportunity to review this spectacular concert DVD and CD. The clarity of the audio recording and the picture itself is  amazing, and they didn't hack the concert in the editing room when it was put from DVD to CD. You get almost the entire audio recording on the CD, including most of the verbal contact Sarah has with the audience. I think this CD is 100 times better than the Harem World Tour CD recording, which makes this package a totally worthwhile purchase. The photos are stunning and the printing of the glossy booklet make everything look so nice. The DVD is purple and the CD is black, with silver lettering on both. As for the artwork of the DVD insert, there is silver lettering on both front and back. The interview with some of the Cathedral's staff is really nice and they show just how appreiative they were of having Sarah perform in their majestic historical building.Sarah's costumes and hair are gorgeous and she is definitely glowing and looking more pretty than ever. There is one small difference from the studio recording of "Fleurs Du Mal" and the recording in this package. What I'm saying is...Sarah doesn't do that high-pitched vocalise while the violin solo comes in in the intro of the song, compared to the studio album recording. I wonder if it would've wrecked the intro to the song if she did sing it while moving down the middle aisle."Sanvean" written by Lisa Gerrard (Dead Can Dance) is a beautiful vocalise consisting of no lyrics but just sounds. That is what I love about this song. It's just so haunting and original, and Sarah does it very well, even if some say she's too breathy. "Canto Della Terra" is beautiful and Alessandro Safina looks and sounds amazing as Sarah's duet partner. Together, they blow everyone away with their breathtaking live rendition of the song. "Atessa" is very pretty and much better than expected. It really doesn't appear they used any playback for this concert, meaning Sarah used her own voice for the whole recording. I was actually expecting Atessa to be dubbed from the studio recording because of that very outstanding high note at th end, which is incredibly hard to do without screaming it."POTO" turned out to be quite nice, although it was a little too fast-paced compared to the original version. But the rock concert edge gives it a totally new edge and Sarah was still able to sing over the volume of the rock band and the pipe organ high above her and Chris Thompson. Oh, that reminds me, my only negative comment would be....Chris Thompson looks like someone they dragged off the street to duet with Sarah. He sounded a little tired in "I will be with you". He sounded winded although he still had a rock edge to his voice...and to his style. But, on "POTO" he and Sarah really blew me away when I watched the performance for the 1st time.It's really wonderful to have this beautiful DVD&CD; package and I'll cherish it for many years to come. This is by far, Sarah's best live performance on DVD, to date...although there are some really amazing live performances on her other live DVDs. But this one really showcases Sarah's live singing voice, and how well she can work with a rock band. Get this item and you'll agree, it's totally worth the wait and the money.

reviewText: I think the title of this review says it all: Great Concert Performance. Excellent Music. Superb Singing. Beautiful Choreography. Plus, excellent video and sound quality for a DVD. I wish it were available on Blu-Ray Disc. Sarah Brightman has an angelic voice. She is a very talented singer and performer. She is beautiful, both spiritually and physically. Overall, this is an all around beautiful concert.
summary: Great Concert Performance. Excellent Music. Superb Singing. Beautiful Choreography. Excellent Video and Sound Quality DVD.

reviewText: I attended the Symphony concert in my town, 2nd row, and it was outstanding. As is this DVD/CD set.  Sarah's voice brings tears to my eyes and I never tire of listening to her CD's over and over.Fernando Lima's voice with Sarah's is a perfect blend. Gorgeous couple on stage, I might add.  My favorite song on the CD was "Pasion". I was disappointed with Chris Thompson singing the part of "I will be with You", and think Paul Stanley's voice is much much better. I did not like Chris singing in "Phantom of the Opera" either. Too raspy and rough. Spectacular location, videography, lighting, outfits!  Sarah is awesome!

reviewText: If Sarah Brightman possesses anything, it is professional integrity.  Every detail of her musical and stage productions exude a style, elegance and grace seen by few performers of her day.  Meticulous with details, she truly strives to transport her fans to a different world.With "Live in Vienna" Brightman has truly delivered a stunning concert both visually and musically.  The setting, the Cathedral Stephensdom in Vienna.  The cinematography fused with the breathtaking visuals creates an amazing experience for the viewer.Either draped in a red stunning gown or a metallic gold corset, the style of the early renaissance clearly comes across in the custom made couture.Brightman soars through nearly all the tracks from her most recent platinum release "Symphony".  The songs from Symphony draw inspiration from gothic musical aspects, creating a rock/metal influenced operatic sound.  "Fleurs Du Mal" (The opening song) sets the bar high.  The song infuses rock and opera elements flawlessly giving it a very new yet familiar sound.  The highlight of the evening comes when Brightman teams up with Chris Thompson on the rock inspired duet "Phantom of the opera"  The song is given a modern makeover complete with bombastic drums and a powerful organ.By concerts end, Brightman reminds us why she is the most successful soprano in history (Over 26 million records sold) when she delivers the stunning "Time To Say Good-bye", poignant for such a special and enchanting evening.

reviewText: I'm a huge Sarah Brightman fan.  However, I'm not a fan of playback that is much louder than the live vocals being sung.  It makes the live vocals sound like THEY are the backing track.  Pie Jesu is an excellent opening going straight into Fleurs du Mal.  Ave Maria as the ending perfect as well.  It's like going on a journey.  Asking God for spiritual guidance at the start and thanking Santa Maria at the end.

reviewText: I love Sarah Brightman's voice, and upon seeing her live performances on dvd, I can also say that I love her stage performance as well, from the elaborate outfits to the stage design (or in this case, the lovely cathedral). It really does take you to another world. This is the second dvd I own of hers, the first being the Live From Las Vegas tour. I'd have to say that the Vegas tour is my favorite, but this Vienna tour has a different vibe and easily stands on its own. What I mean is that it doesn't feel like you're watching the same performance in a different country, which can happen with some musicians. Now I have two Sarah Brightman dvds to enjoy!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sarah opens this gorgeous evening with "Pie Jesu," from the Reqiuem Mass. She faces the altar and the tones and notes resonate so beautifully from her toward the altar. When "Fleurs Du Mal" begins with its electric instrumentation and choral accents, Sarah grabs the hem of her scarlet gown and dramatically floats down the aisle. She is a vision in red, seemingly moving away from a malicious force to the altar for comfort. At this point, you know that you are in for a treat! ...and, my oh my, are you!As is her specialty, modern musical accents blend with the classic works of yore, and Sarah Brightman is a capable vehicle for it all. She never lets up. Her vocals are impeccable throughout. Among the highlights of the concert (which are innumerable) are: "Sarai Qui," "Running," "Let It Rain," and an unforgettable performance of "Phantom of the Opera" with Chris Thompson.If you are a Sarah Brightman fan, a fan of music, or looking for classy and timeless entertainment, then this concert and the audio recording of the evening will delight you again and again! BRAVO SARAH!
summary: Divine! A wonderful treat from Sarah Brightman.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What a wonderful CD/DVD concert combo! The 5.1/DTS sound is so clear and not muddy like in the usual concerts. In fact, if you do not hear the applause at the end of the songs, it would be hard to tell if it's live .... This is an amazing concert, however, I have a few "cons" but more on that later.The location is just magnificient, beautiful historic cathedral in Vienna. All the songs are so good but the ones that stand out for me are Fleurs Du Mal, Symphony, Passion, the Phamtom of the Opera has a more rock edge version and the two outstanding duets with Alessandro Safina. I must admit that I was surprise at the beginning when I saw the drummer who looks like Sarah just dragged him out of a rock band and the guitarist with a double-deck on his neck ...  WTF! ... I wasn't sure if I was watching the right concert or not but after I heard Fleurs Du Mal, it just blowed me away and I knew I was in for a treat, this is cross-over at its best. The extras are good, Sarah talks about the songs, the guests and the production, nothing fancy in here, just some good information.Now, some of my "cons". First, I feel that Sarah is too breathy, like when you hear outstanding songs like Symphony (or Sarai Qui) and you keep hearing the heavy inhale, that dimishes the experience a little, althought that is still one heck of a song, ... or should I blame the sound engineer for not catching this, hello! ... Second, to give the fan a concert to remember with this perfect setting, she could have brought the "real" phantom, M.Crawford, for the duet rather than with C.Thompson. Chris is doing a good job with a more rock edge version but he is nowhere near the real phantom. Third, Sarah did not introduce the band who did a marvelous job that night, or unless she did but the producer decided not to include it in the DVD which I think is a shame because they deserve to be recognized.Overall, this is one of Sarah's best concert since Eden. The location, lighting, videography, dresses and songs selection are top notch. Ms Brightman also looks more beautiful and slimmer than ever! I like this CD/DVD combo since I can watch the DVD at home and listen to the CD in the car, what a novel idea!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I stumbled upon this concert a couple years ago on PBS along with its crummy 2.0 soundtrack.  Although this DVD is not in High Definition it comes damn close.  It has a beautiful transfer and comes with a 5.1 Dolby or DTS soundtrack.  Sarah's voice remains as strong as ever and I must say she gets more beautiful with age.  I'm guessing she may have had a lift or two but she certainly has left her baby fat well behind her.  She's smokin' with all those corseted gowns, of which she changes 4 or 5 times.  Along for the ride are 3 fellas that sing with her on a few of the tunes.  Granted, several of the songs are repeated favorites of many concerts, but there is also some new material.  The setting is the Stephansdome Cathedral which originated much of history's classical music and is a gothic structure of some renown.  A very nice concert.
summary: 4 1/2 stars for another fine Brightman concert
Title: N/A

reviewText: As much as I love Sarah Brightman and her work, I stayed away from this DVD for a while because of the loud, bombastic, Goth-rock theme. Only recently I decided to take the leap and watch it.I surprised myself by liking this concert immensely, and aside from a few songs (Fleurs du Mal, Sanvean, I Will Be With You) and several brief moments here and there, I found it rather enjoyable. I'm not a big fan of rock music, and probably wouldn't have bought this if not for the classical pieces included. The title song "Symphony" seems like one that she's really got a good hold of, and one that has a great classical-pop crossover feel. "Running" is probably my favorite out of all of them, with Sarah's rich, operatic soprano really taking control at the beginning and end. It reminded me a lot of "A Question Of Honor". "Attesa", "Storia D'Amore", and "Pie Jesu" are amazing, though not quite as well-executed as the original recordings; but nothing can compare with "Ave Maria", which Sarah uses to close the concert. Her performance is nothing less than angelic.As far as vocals, Sarah's voice doesn't seem as strong as it was in the "Harem" concert during some of the pieces, and occasionally goes a bit sharp and shrieky. I had read that Sarah had recently recovered from a severe illness before starting the concert, so this may be a consequence of that. Even so, I was a bit surprised to hear her voice so strained on some pieces; every once and a while, it came close to hurting my ears. All I can say is I hope that her voice has recovered since then and has returned to normal.Even with these impediments, Sarah still remains a great singer, but she sure isn't a rock singer. Most of the pieces that I thought she didn't sound as good on were the rock ballads, which just shows that her voice just isn't as well suited to the rougher, less lyrical pieces as she is to the more classical, operatic ones.The concert's setting, inside a beautiful old Gothic church in Vienna, fits marvelously with the songs she has chosen. Audio and visual are a lot clearer than on Harem, and the camera work is done splendidly, panning over the marvelous Gothic ceiling and architecture of the church, not to mention the gorgeous carvings; and then zooming in on Sarah at just the right moments while she sings. The lighting is also very dramatic, with bright, vivid colors and great use of shadows and effects. It looks great on film.Sarah is as pretty as always, with a new hairstyle and less makeup than on "Harem", though her gowns for this concert seem a little too low cut, especially the white number she wears during the last few songs, but that's just me. I personally thought her outfits in Eden and Harem were a lot better.Apart from her solo performances, she also has no less than five duets with numerous partners. Alessandro Safina has a fine voice and makes a good stand-in for Andrea Bocelli, who sang "Canto Della Terra" with her on the studio album. He also does a nice job on "Sarai Qui". Fernando Lima has a sweet counter-tenor voice, which is a little ticklish on the ears, but is all right. The only thing I didn't like about him was his bedraggled appearance. With his long, unkempt hair, he doesn't fit at all with Brightman's queenly appearance, but looks aren't a big deal as long as he can sing, which he can."The Phantom of the Opera" was exciting, if not done at a little too fast a tempo, but it could have been absolutely electrifying if the guy playing the Phantom actually had a good voice. (It's Chris Thompson, who sounds like nails on a chalkboard; he's as bad as Steve Harley was on the 1985 music video, with absolutely no chemistry between him and Sarah at all). Sarah is amazing, but unfortunately, the heavy rock beat and hum of electric guitars drowns out her voice almost completely and makes this one hard to listen to, even at a moderate volume. As much as I am glad she included this one, the overpowering rock thread makes it less enjoyable than it should have been."Sanvean" was the only classical piece I didn't enjoy, partly for the fact that it is just vocalizing and no words, and that it seemed a little whispery.This package includes everything the $15 live CD package has as far as music and video extras go, but this also includes the full DVD of the live concert in Vienna. The extra features themselves are nice, with two interviews with Sarah about the songs and the whole "Symphony" album, and two more with experts on the church the concert was filmed in. Finally, the included audio CD has all the tracks from the DVD,live, plus an extra studio track "Vide Cor Meum", which was nice choice to end the album on a gentle note.All in all, I don't think this is one of Sarah Brightman's best artistic endeavors (I hope next time she'll go a little closer to her roots), but at the same time it made me glad that I finally decided to go ahead and watch it.
summary: "Symphony": Not as bad as I thought it would be.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sarah Brightman's Symphony is set in a rather unusual venue - a 800 year old Viennese cathedral with a Gothic exterior. The equally Gothic interior is covered by expansive Diamond/Checkered flooring.Songs are carefully selected to fit with the Church feel. Some of them are chosen because they sound like hymns.There are two stages - one at either end of the long Cathedral. Watching this is kind of not static. Sarah walks up and down the aisle to sing at either one of the stages. In Phantom Of The Opera, she is perched on top of the pipe organ with her guest vocalist Chris Thompson - overlooking the audience. It feels just like arch angels watching over the congregation. Other showstoppers include her duets with Alessandro Safina on Andre Bocelli's Canto Della Terra and a opera version of Sarai Qui (There You'll Be). I especially like Pasion, sung together with Fernando Lima.The Cathedral gives this concert an almost a magical flair - just like one is attending mass. Sarah's ethereal voice looms over with a commanding presence of a beautiful angel. It is a visual and aural spectacle to behold.My CD/DVD comes in a DVD case with an accompanying "programme" booklet - making this feel like a great night out at the theatre. So book your "front row seats", fix your self a nice hot Viennesse coffee and savour this exceptional experience.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The gothic setting of St. Stephen's Cathedral in Vienna is a fitting place for a Sarah Brightman concert. It's as dramatic as she is! I enjoy the dark romanticism, beautiful lighting and music, and Brightman's lyrical, operatic voice!My favorites are her pop songs "Symphony" and "Let It Rain." The songs "Pie Jesu" and "Ave Maria" are both ethereal. "Fleurs Du Mal" and "Running" are mixtures of pop and rock and opera. Of her classical duets, I did enjoy "Canto Della Terra" and "Sarai Qui"* (with Alessandro Safina) and "Pasion" (with Fernando Lima). Her rendition of "The Phamton of the Opera" with Chris Thompson isn't as impressive, however. Thompson's hoarse singing voice and shouting gives me headaches. He obviously struggles throughout the entire song, where he lacks the range to reach the higher notes! "Time to Say Goodbye," just isn't the same when performed as a solo. I love this better as a duet. Yet I do prefer Brightman's solo of these piece over Bocelli's.Brightman's younger sister, Amelia (aka Violet), is also in this production providing background vocals and keyboard.The DVD extras include worthwhile interviews with Brightman about the concert production and songs. Also, interviews with Father Anthony Faber and historian, Elisabeth Lloyd-Davis, provide a brief, but interesting overview about the magnificent Stephansdom--including a snippet of Mozart's Vienna home, (which I'm fortunate enough to have visited).Overall, a great buy! This is a very well-done production--and highly recommended!!*A rendition of Diane Warren's "There You'll Be," performed by Faith Hill for the movie, "Pearl Harbor."
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sarah Brightman's latest live concert, filmed in St Stephen's Cathedral in Vienna is a winner on all fronts. Featuring a dazzling lineup of songs from her current album Symphony, outstanding guest artists, a pickup orchestra and frontline rhythm section, her long-standing admirers will certainly not be disappointed. The Cathedral provides an atmospheric setting for Sarah to showcase both classical and popular repertoire with consumate ease. With so many highlights to choose from, her duets with Italian tenor Alessandro Safina, Manfred Mannvocalist Chris Thompson and Spanish counter-tenor Fernando Lima are most memorable. The show also features several older hits, among them Pie Jesu, Phantom of the Opera, Ave Maria and Time to say Goodbye.
summary: Another brilliant concert from Ms Brightman

reviewText: I'm getting spoiled with watching her other big well done productions, like Harem. Still this was a nice little production. This DVD was a nice small production done in the Church and comes also with a music CD. Great lighting and great music orchestration, as usual. Her voice is still the best female voice in the world, because of the range and cross over music from opera to pop. I always love her dresses and being so beautiful and feminine. She's not afraid of looking like a woman with beautiful dresses. She's always a class act. She still owes us a DVD of her latest live concert that has been all over the world. Can't wait for that one to come out.
summary: Not a big production, but lovely

reviewText: Sarah Brightman. Sometimes, I just don't know which way I'm going. If I'm I'm going away from Sarah, she drags me back. Maybe, I just can't go away from Sarah. Maybe, deep down inside, I don't want to. But even if I try, she keeps bringing me back again.Such is the case with her SYMPHONY LIVE IN VIENNA release. (What do I have now, about 4 of these, bewtween the CD and the DVD)? Is 4 enough? I don't know. Maybe not, with Sarah.This incredibly, unbelievably talented lady takes you on an emotional rollercoaster ride with her music. One minute you are peaceful, serene, listening to "LET IT RAIN". The next minute, you are 10 miles high, screaming along with the powerhouse "RUNNING". "THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA" will amaze you and enchant you. And one of MY favorites will always be the number "SYMPHONY".I'm not really sure of how to describe Sarah. Or her music. It's a mix I guess. Some Opera. Some hard-driving Rock. Some Pop. Some Orchestral music. Symphony. Choral. Chamber music. Take that and put it all in a blender and presto ... SARAH BRIGHTMAN.But ya know what? No matter what you want to call this, it has become one of my favorite 'types' of music. Sarah has a magical touch. Actually, she could just stand there. Nothing else. Just stand there, on stage, and you will love her.It's tough to tear myself away from Sarah. And her music. I find that, once I put one of her discs in, it's in for quite some time. Days. Even weeks. Before I replace it with something else.So, what am I saying here? I'm saying this: if you think you might like some Opera. Or, some Symphony. Or, some choral. Or, some hard-driving Rock ... all mixed together into some phenomenally remarkable music ... better check Sarah out.
Title: N/A
